title: DOES THE SEC TRULY HAVE THE BIGGEST HOME FIELD ADVANTAGE IN COLLEGE FOOTBALL?
text:
College football isn’t just a game, it’s a thrilling experience that draws the attention of so many. With these exciting games and atmospheres, the home field advantage becomes more and more of a factor.
Many teams enjoy a unique advantage when playing on their home field in college football. Let’s look at some numbers to explore why the SEC is named to have the biggest home field advantage compared to other conferences.
In fact, does the SEC have the biggest home court advantage?
When looking at some data sets from the college football season of 2022, it becomes clear that the SEC conference stands out in some aspects.
The first question is going to be how do college football teams perform in terms of points scored in home and away games, and does this show anything significant? Here is a breakdown off the average points scored by each conference at home and away.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(ggbump)
library(gt)
library(wehoop)
library(patchwork)

football <- read_csv("footballlogs22.csv")

Pointsscored <- football |>
  group_by(Conference) |>
  summarize(PointsscoredHomeAway = sum(TeamScore + OpponentScore))

home <- football |>
  filter(is.na(HomeAway) == "TRUE")

OppscoreH <- football |>
  group_by(Conference) |>
  filter(is.na(HomeAway) == "TRUE") |>
  summarize(OpponentScoreHome = mean(OpponentScore))

homepoints <- home |>
  group_by(Conference) |>
  summarize(Pointsathome = mean(TeamScore))


away <- football |>
  filter(HomeAway == "@")


OppscoreA <- football |>
  group_by(Conference) |>
filter(HomeAway == "@")
  

awaypoints <- away |>
  group_by(Conference) |>
  summarize(Pointsaway = mean(TeamScore))

ggplot() + 
  geom_bump(data=Pointsscored, aes(x=PointsscoredHomeAway, y=Conference, color=Conference)) +
  geom_bump(data=homepoints, aes(x=Pointsathome, y=Conference, color=Conference)) +
  geom_point(data=homepoints, aes(x=Pointsathome, y=Conference, color=Conference), size = 4) +
  geom_bump(data=awaypoints, aes(x=Pointsaway, y=Conference, color=Conference)) +
  geom_point(data=awaypoints, aes(x=Pointsaway, y=Conference, color=Conference), size = 2) +
  
  labs(
  title="Average points scored in college football", 
  subtitle="Big cirlce are points scored at home. Small circle are points away",
  caption = "Source: Sports Reference | By Nic Wiedenhorn",
   y= "Conference", 
  x = "Points scored") +
  theme_minimal() +
  
  
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 





This chart reveals the average points scored at home and the points scored away for each conference. It shows that the SEC is one of the highest scoring conferences at home, which shows dominance on their home turf.
Some other teams might have a bigger point margin or points scored at home but to look for a bigger indicator, let’s have a look at the number of games won at home and away in the SEC.
Is there a significant difference between the performance of the SEC compared to any other conference when playing at home or away?


Code
Totalgames <- football |>
  filter(TeamScore > -1) |>
  group_by(Conference) |>
  summarize(TotalGames = n())
  

Home <- football |>
  filter(is.na(HomeAway) == "TRUE")

Homewins <- Home |>
  group_by(Conference) |>
  filter(Outcome == "W") |>
   summarize(HomeWins = n()) 

bar2 <- ggplot() + geom_bar(data=Homewins, aes(x=reorder(Conference,HomeWins),weight=HomeWins)) +
  coord_flip()

Away <- football |>
  group_by(Conference) |>
  filter(HomeAway == "@", Outcome=="W") |>
  summarize(AwayWins = n())


bar3 <- ggplot() + geom_bar(data=Away, aes(x=reorder(Conference,AwayWins),weight=AwayWins)) +
  coord_flip()

SEC <- Homewins |> filter(Conference == "Southeastern Conference") 
SEC2 <- Away |> filter(Conference == "Southeastern Conference")
bar2 <- ggplot() + geom_bar(data=Homewins, aes(x=reorder(Conference,HomeWins),weight=HomeWins), fill="grey") +
  geom_bar(data=SEC, aes(x=reorder(Conference,HomeWins),weight=HomeWins), fill="red") +
  coord_flip() +
  labs(
    x="Conference", 
    y="Wins at Home"
    ) + 
  theme_minimal() 

bar3 <- ggplot() + geom_bar(data=Away, aes(x=reorder(Conference,AwayWins),weight=AwayWins), fill="grey") +
  geom_bar(data=SEC2, aes(x=reorder(Conference,AwayWins),weight=AwayWins), fill="red") +
  coord_flip() +
  labs(
    x="Conference", 
    y="Wins Away") + 
  theme_minimal() 

bar2 + bar3 + 
  plot_annotation(
    title = "This shows the amount of college football games won at home and away",
    subtitle = "Games won in each conference depending on the place.",
    caption = "Source: Sports Reference | By Nic Wiedenhorn"
  )  & 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 14, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  )





These bar charts represent the amount of games won at home and games won on the road. The red bar represents the SEC conference and shows how much they stand out at home. This shows the hard challenge for teams in the SEC playing away.
What conclusions can be drawn when looking at the win percentage of the SEC and other conferences at home and away games, and does this support the challenge of playing at the SEC?


Code
home_data <- football |>
  filter(is.na(HomeAway) == "TRUE") |>
  group_by(Conference) |>
  summarize(HomeWins = mean(Outcome == "W"))

away_data <- football |>
  filter(HomeAway == "@") |>
  group_by(Conference) |>
  summarize(AwayWins = mean(Outcome == "W"))

confwins <- home_data |> inner_join(away_data)

confwins |>
  gt() |>
  cols_label(
    HomeWins = "HomeWinPercentage",
    
    AwayWins = "AwayWinPercentage",
    
  ) |>
    fmt_percent(
    columns = c(HomeWins,AwayWins),
    decimals = 1
  ) |>
  tab_header(
    title = "Is the SEC the hardest conference to play away?",
    subtitle = "The SEC has the highest home win percenate out of every conference."
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")
  ) |>
  tab_source_note(
    source_note = md("Source: Sports Reference | By Nic Wiedenhorn")
  ) |>
  tab_style(
     locations = cells_column_labels(columns = everything()),
     style = list(
       cell_borders(sides = "bottom", weight = px(3)),
       cell_text(weight = "bold", size=12)
     )
  ) |>
  opt_row_striping() |> 
  opt_table_lines("none") |>
    
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "red"),
      cell_text(color = "white")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = Conference == "Southeastern Conference")
  )

In conclusion, these graphics show that the SEC has the most games won at home by far with the biggest win percentage at home. That shows that teams in the SEC don’t only face skillful teams but also have to overcome the challenge of playing on the road. The SEC isn’t just a hard football conference, it’s a challenge to overcome for those who want to be National Champions.

title: IS THE SERVICE PLACEMENT MORE IMPORTANT THAN THE SPEED ON THE ATP TOUR?
text:
Tennis is a sport where the serve is one of the biggest weapons, often even decides about the outcome of matches. In tennis the serve always starts the point and is the only shot in tennis where the opponent has no influence on and therefore very important. This analysis is going to dive into the importance of how placement and speed will influence the chance to hold serve.
One of the most important aspects of the serve is the variability. Each ace can be a game changer, but a double fault could also mean trouble. The service quality can depend on many reasons like the height, technique, racket and many more but what’s the most important on the serve?
There is a lot of strategy included which sets the tone for the service games. This analysis is going to look into the average serve speed of the first and second serve as well as the placement measured in aces and how that influences the chance to hold serve.
Let’s take a look at the average serving speed at the ATP Finals. The two highlighted players are arguably the best players in the world right now.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(patchwork)
library(ggalt)
library(ggtext)
library(gt)
library(wehoop)
library(patchwork)

firstservespeed <- read_csv("1ServeAveragSpeedProject.csv")

secondservespeed <- read_csv("2ServeAverageSpeedProject.csv")

firstservespeed <- firstservespeed |>
  mutate(value = gsub(" km/h", "", value, fixed = TRUE), value = as.numeric(value))

secondservespeed <- secondservespeed |>
  mutate(value = gsub(" km/h", "", value, fixed = TRUE), value = as.numeric(value))
 

Sinner1 <- firstservespeed |> filter(name == "Jannik Sinner") 
Djokovic1 <- firstservespeed |> filter(name == "Novak Djokovic")
Sinner2 <- secondservespeed |> filter(name == "Jannik Sinner") 
Djokovic2 <- secondservespeed |> filter(name == "Novak Djokovic") 
bar1 <- ggplot() +
geom_bar(data=firstservespeed, aes(x=reorder(name,value),weight=value),fill="grey") +
geom_bar(data=Sinner1, aes(x=reorder(name,value),weight=value),fill="blue") +
geom_bar(data=Djokovic1, aes(x=reorder(name,value),weight=value),fill="red") +  
  coord_flip() + 
  labs(
    x="", 
    y="Average First Serve Speed"
    ) + 
  theme_minimal()

bar2 <- ggplot() +
geom_bar(data=secondservespeed, aes(x=reorder(name,value),weight=value),fill="grey") +
geom_bar(data=Sinner2, aes(x=reorder(name,value),weight=value),fill="blue") +
geom_bar(data=Djokovic2, aes(x=reorder(name,value),weight=value),fill="red") + 
coord_flip() +  
  labs(
    x="", 
    y="Average Second Serve Speed") + 
  theme_minimal() 


bar1 + bar2 +
  plot_annotation(
    title = "Average Serving Speed During ATP Finals",
    subtitle = "Average speed for first and second serve in KM/H.",
    caption = "Source: Ultimate Tennis Statistics | By Nic Wiedenhorn"
  ) & 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 10), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  )





This chart shows the comparison of the average serve speed of all players for the first and second serve. That considered, let’s take a look at the two highlighted players. These two performed the best in the tournament and ended up playing in the finals against each other.
Looking at this statistic, both are in the middle or bottom part of the chart even though they played the finals against each other. Maybe there is another reason why they had better service games.
Does this mean the serve speed is necessary for a good service game?
Let’s take a look at the number of aces and doubles faults from each player.


Code
 Aces <- read_csv("AcesProject.csv")


doublefaults <- read_csv("DoublefaultsProject.csv")

doublef <- doublefaults |>
  group_by(name) |>
  filter(value > 0) |>
  summarise(
    DoubelFaults = sum(value)
  ) |>
  arrange(desc(DoubelFaults))

AcesDoublefaults <- Aces |> inner_join(doublef)

ggplot() + 
  geom_dumbbell(
    data=AcesDoublefaults, 
    aes(y=reorder(name, active), x=value, xend=DoubelFaults),
    size = 2,
    colour = "grey",
    colour_x = "green",
    colour_xend = "red") +
  labs(
    title="Aces vs Doublefaults at the ATP Finals", 
    subtitle = "If <span style = 'color:green;'>Aces</span> are on the right, that's good. If <span style = 'color:red;'>Doublefaults</span> are on the right, that's bad.",
    caption = "Source: Ultimate Tennis Statistics | By Nic Wiedenhorn", 
    x="Ace Doublefault Difference",
    y=""
    
  ) + 
  theme_minimal() +
 theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 11), 
    plot.subtitle = element_textbox_simple(size=11), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 





Double faults are always part of the game but the greater the difference the better. When looking at this chart it becomes clear that the precision which can be seen as aces can have a very big impact on the service games.
This chart presented the balance between aces and double faults for each player. Without even highlighting the two players from before we can see that they stand out. Djokovic and Sinner have an average amount of double faults but when it comes to aces the are way ahead.
What conclusion can be drawn when looking at the number of aces and double faults in regards of service game holds? Let’s look which players hold their serve more than others in comparison.


Code
winpercentage <- read_csv("ServiceGamesWon%.csv")

onlygames <- winpercentage |>
  select(rank,name,value)

aces <- read_csv("AcesProject.csv")

 
  
Newaces <- aces |>
  group_by(name) |>
  summarise(
    TotalAces = sum(value)
  ) |>
  arrange(desc(TotalAces))

aceswins <- Newaces |> inner_join(onlygames) |>
  select(name, TotalAces, value) |>
  arrange(desc(value))

aceswins |>
  gt() |>
  cols_label(
    value = "Service Games Won"
    
  ) |>
    fmt_percent(
    columns = c(value),
    decimals = 1
  ) |>
  tab_header(
    title = "Do players with more aces hold serve more often?",
    subtitle = "This table shows the percentage of service games won."
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")
  ) |>
  tab_source_note(
    source_note = md("Source: Sports Reference | By Nic Wiedenhorn")
  ) |>
  tab_style(
     locations = cells_column_labels(columns = everything()),
     style = list(
       cell_borders(sides = "bottom", weight = px(3)),
       cell_text(weight = "bold", size=12)
     )
  ) |>
  opt_row_striping() |> 
  opt_table_lines("none") |>
    
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "blue"),
      cell_text(color = "white")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = name == "Jannik Sinner")
  ) |>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "red"),
      cell_text(color = "white")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = name == "Novak Djokovic")
  )
